ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Watched the recorded lecture a few times when I couldn't make it to the scheduled time

Lecture streamed live on Zoom + later posted as a recording on Canvas. 
We also had a synchronous discussion section over Zoom.
Due to time difference I mostly watched the recorded lectures (always uploaded most timely!

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned about some general concepts and founders of sociology. A skill I continued to develop was looking at things in multiple perspectives

I got a thorough survey of the different theorists that have contributed to the development of cultural sociology as a field, as well as some specific applications of cultural sociology in contemporary scenarios.
Overview of the field of cultural sociology in a nutshell; the reading materials are just classic and most are very interesting to read (though can be challenging as well
A culturally based viewpoint of sociology.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths: the TF Vanessa, the lectures that were related to current social issues

Weaknesses: Readings were not engaging, lecture style (reading a script without any slides/activities to break it up) was not interesting for me, scheduled meeting time (4-5:15 pm). I did not like having so many auditors in the course because it felt more geared towards them rather than the undergrads.
The course material is interesting, but definitely dense. The class is strongest when the theory is being applied to scenarios that students are already familiar with.

Wonderful class if one is interested in digging deep in cultural sociology or sociology in general! The reading materials are amazing but sometimes the reading loads can vary from week to week quite substantially; it would also be great if we could get more feedbacks on our weekly reading response
The lectures could be more engaging.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: It was helpful to have the lectures recorded.
The ability to ask questions at the end of every lecture was an engaging component.
The recorded lectures are just really helpful!

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: No, I would not. Although the professor is clearly established, I did not feel excited or look forward to the course over the semester.

Yes, if they are specifically interested in sociology or cultural theory. I certainly don't think it's a class for EVERYONE, but anyone interested in those areas and is willing to work through some of the theory would find it interesting.
Yes! Professor Alexander's contributions to the field of cultural sociology are just amazing!
Yes. It was a very interesting course about a very interesting topic.
